newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Asian air traffic grows fastest - Airbus.
newsitem.headline: Asian air traffic grows fastest - Airbus.

text.p: The airlines of the Asia-Pacific region will experience the strongest growth in the world over the next 20 years and will be the dominant market for new civil aircraft, Airbus Industrie said on Tuesday.

The European aircraft consortium predicted in a study that air passenger traffic to, from and within the Asia Pacific region would rise at an average rate of 6.4 percent per year to 2016, compared with a world average rate of 5.2 percent.
Worldwide, Airbus predicted potential aircraft deliveries over the next 20 years would reach 15,800, worth $1,100 billion. The Asia Pacific region would account for around $375 billion.
By 2016, Airbus expected the total global fleet of civil passenger aircraft to grow to 17,100.
"Airbus Industrie's stated goal is to obtain at least 50 percent of all potential new sales beyond the year 2000," the statement said.
It said the high growth in the Asia Pacific region would generate a requirement for triple the number of airline seats currently available.
By 2016, Asia Pacific demand would rise to 1.3 million seats, or 32 percent of world capacity, from around 416,000 at present.
Within Asia, the highest increase would be in China, where domestic traffic would grow by 10 percent per year, it said.
Airbus predicted the average size of aircraft operated in the region would rise to 312 seats, from 232 seats.
Altogether, the total fleet in the Asia Pacific region would more than double in size to 4,100 from 1,800 currently.

Airbus is a consortium of Ste Nationale Industrielle Aerospatiale of France and Daimler-Benz Aerospace -- a unit of Daimler Benz AG of Germany, British Aerospace and Spain's Construcciones Aeronauticas SA.
